review.title: A Systematic Review of Hindi Prosody
review.abstract: Prosody describes both form and function of a sentence using the suprasegmental features of speech. Prosody phenomena are explored in the domain of higher phonological constituents such as word, phonological phrase and intonational phrase. The study of prosody at the word level is called word prosody and above word level is called sentence prosody. Word Prosody describes stress pattern by comparing the prosodic features of its constituent syllables. Sentence Prosody involves the study on phrasing pattern and intonatonal pattern of a language. The aim of this study is to summarize the existing works on Hindi prosody carried out in different domain of language and speech processing. The review is presented in a systematic fashion so that it could be a useful resource for one who wants to build on the existing works.

sections.heading: INTRODUCTION
sections.text: Prosody is an important aspect of spoken language. A slight modulation in prosody can lead to changes in the meaning of an utterance. Prosody is studied at various levels in various branches of science and engineering. In linguistics, the leading branches contributing to knowledge of prosody are phonetics, phonology, syntax, semantics and psycholinguistics. In cognitive science, neurophysiological traits such as the spectrotemporal property of cortical oscillation in theta, beta, gamma and delta band are used as keywords for prosody research. Finally, engineers use these traits to develop an automatic module for categorizing prosodic events. The modern standard Hindi is an Indo-Aryan language spoken mainly in North India, and also an official language of Fiji. It is spoken by 422 million Hindi speakers in India (census 2001), and prosody is the prosody language that follows the SOdi word synthesis with the order of the European Hindi language.

sections.heading: Phonological/Prosodic Phrasing: A Production-Perception Based Study
sections.text: (Jyothi et. al., 2014) investigate prosodic prominence and prosodic phrases by designing a production-perception-based experiment using two types of informants for perceptual analysis: i) non-experts and ii) experts. Judgment-based analysis calculated the paired kappa value for prosodic prominence and prosodic phrases between non-experts and non-expert notes. Their analysis suggests that there is less agreement for prosodic prominence and prosodic phrases between non-experts as well as between experts and non-expert notes. However, there is a good match for both prosodic prominence and prosodic phrases notes between expert listeners. (Gryllia et. al., 2015) analyze the phonological phrase in Hindi and the data for this purpose.

sections.heading: Computational Model of Hindi Intonation
sections.text: (Rao and Yegnanarayana, 2009) used the neural network on labeled news broadcast data in Hindi. Labeling is done for pitch contour at the syllable level. The neural network was trained using position constraints (position of a syllable at the beginning and end of utterance), contextual constraints (how many syllables precede a syllable and follow it by indicating its characteristics) and phonological characteristics. The study reported an accuracy of 88% in determining the pitch pattern associated with syllables. (Madhukumar et. al., 2013) examined the pattern of f0 contours in Hindi explanatory sentences and question sets. Declarative sentences show declension in f0 contour, while the sentences in question exhibit rising f0 contour. Their analysis suggests that the decreasing and increasing pattern of f0 contour is caused by the phonological pattern of their constituent words.

sections.heading: CONCLUSION
sections.text: The paper summarizes the existing work on Hindi word prosody and sentence prosody; the phonological representation of the rules for stress placement at the word level is described in detail; the phonetic stimuli associated with the stressed unit at the word level are also described on the basis of previous studies; the important facts on Hindi intonation and phonological phonology suggested in various literature are described; the computer model for prosodic modulation, such as the duration model and the intonation model, are discussed in this review; the discussion of the duration model using CART and neural networks at the phoneme and syllable levels is included; and the implementation of neural networks at the f0 contour was also described.
